H0.text: Friction is the force that causes a ball thrown up into the air to fall to the ground.

H1.text: Gravity is the force that causes a ball thrown up into the air to fall to the ground.

H2.text: Magnetism is the force that causes the ball to fall to the ground when it is thrown up into the air.

H3.text: Electricity is the force that causes the ball to fall to the ground when it is thrown up into the air.

A4.text: Gravity is the force that every object with mass attracts every other object in the universe in proportion to each mass and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

A5.text: In the late 16th century, Galileo Galilei's careful measurements of balls rolling down inclines allowed him to firmly establish that gravitational acceleration is the same for all objects.
